data.title: "Smart Move by Netflix," Bernstein Says NFLX's Decision to Walk Away Is a Win-Win-Win in WBD's Takeover Battle
data.description:
Bernstein analyst Laurent Yoon said Netflix's (NFLX) choice to walk away from the Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) deal is not a setback at all, but a smart move that will allow the company to refocus on its core strengths. He also argued that the outcome ultimately creates a win‑win‑win scenario for all three companies involved in the takeover battle.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Yoon highlighted that Netflix backed out within hours of WBD formally declaring Paramount Skydance's (PSKY) offer a "Company Superior Proposal." Netflix has long been known for disciplined capital allocation, and the analyst believes that ultimately guided the move.  Yoon reiterated a Buy rating and $115 price target on Netflix stock.

Why Bernstein Sees a "Win‑Win‑Win" Outcome

Yoon believes each company walks away with something meaningful.

Netflix: He expects NFLX stock to recover to an above-market multiple, implying a move back above $90 per share in the near term. With the deal drama removed, Netflix can return to its core growth formula, focus on pricing power, subscriber growth, and margin expansion, which Yoon says has fueled its long‑term success and should continue to do so.

Paramount Skydance: Even if PSKY is paying a premium, Yoon argued that acquiring WBD is still a better strategic path than continuing a "mediocre standalone trajectory." The deal gives PSKY a chance to reshape its future. Yoon does not expect the company to push the price much higher, but he sees strategic logic in the move.

Warner Bros. Discovery: WBD shareholders have already seen the stock more than double since PSKY first showed interest in September 2025. PSKY's $31‑per‑share all‑cash offer, backed by financing guarantees and a massive $7 billion termination fee, stands out as clearly superior to Netflix's bid.

Which Stock Is a Better Buy?

We used TipRanks' Comparison Tool to line up all three companies in the takeover saga and see which stock analysts favor. According to analysts, Netflix stock has the highest upside potential of 23.98%.
data.author: Radhika Saraogi

data.title: Samsung Stock Jumps Alongside Plans to Reevaluate Its Edge Smartphone Line
data.description:
Samsung Electronics (SSNLF) stock is a hot topic on Friday after the electronic device company revealed that it's considering a shakeup to its smartphone line. Samsung's Mobile Experience Business head, Won-Joon Choi, told Bloomberg that the company is weighing the continuation of its line of ultrathin smartphones.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

According to Choi, the Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge didn't perform as well as the company hoped. This was Samsung's first attempt at mimicking rival Apple's (AAPL) incredibly thin smartphone design philosophy for the iPhone Air. Interestingly, super thin smartphones don't appear to appeal to consumers, as the iPhone Air also didn't perform as well as expected.

Considering the lukewarm reception to the Galaxy S25 Edge, it makes sense that Samsung would consider dropping the line. It would also allow the company to focus on other developments, such as folding smartphones. These have been growing in popularity, though Samsung may have taken the idea a bit too far with its massive Tri-Fold smartphone, which is on the chopping block alongside the Edge line. One fold appears to be enough for consumers, as two folds are too many.

Samsung Stock Movement Today

Samsung Electronics stock was up 54.05% after the markets closed yesterday. Investors will note that this gain came after Nvidia's (NVDA) latest earnings report. This pushed SSNLF stock and SK Hynix shares higher.
data.author: William White

data.title: UBS Downgrades U.S. Stock Market on Dollar Risks, Slowing Buybacks
data.description:
Amid a weak start to the year for the S&P 500 (SPX) compared to its worldwide peers, UBS (UBS) has downgraded American equities to "benchmark" in a fully invested global equity portfolio.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

UBS Head of Global Equity Strategy Andrew Garthwaite notes several concerns, such as a weakening dollar, a slower pace of corporate buybacks, and volatile policies under the Trump administration. The U.S. dollar index, which tracks the greenback against a basket of major currencies, has fallen by nearly 9% over the past year, with Garthwaite predicting that the euro will rise to $1.22 by the end of the first quarter.

Buybacks Cool, Uncertainty Drives U.S. Outflows

In addition, the scale of U.S. corporate buybacks has edged lower and is now broadly in line with the rest of the world. Some of that capital has gone toward building out AI infrastructure as big tech commits hundreds of billions to the mission.

"The buybacks yield is no longer exceptional and this had been an important driver of funds flow, EPS and valuation," wrote Garthwaite in a note.

Finally, the unpredictability of the Trump administration has led to outflows from U.S. stocks. UBS has a year-end price target of 7,500 for the S&P 500, lower than the average Wall Street estimate of 7,629.
data.author: Eddie Pan

data.title: 10-Year Treasury Yield Sinks to 4-Month Low on Inflation, Geopolitical Risks
data.description:
The 10-year Treasury yield is down by 4.2 bps to 3.975%, its lowest level since late October, on a higher-than-expected inflation print and geopolitical developments in the Middle East.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Investors rushed to bid up the 10-year note as a safe-haven asset after the U.S. Producer Price Index (PPI) showed a 2.9% jump in January, well above the consensus estimate of 2.6%. The data also sent the stock market lower. As a reminder, the yield on a note moves in the opposite direction of its price.

10-Year Yield Slips on Rising Middle East Tensions

Meanwhile, the U.S. has ordered its non-emergency embassy staff in Israel to evacuate as its nuclear talks with Iran are set to continue next week in Vienna. The U.S. has been steadily building up its military presence in the Middle East to prepare for potential strikes on Iran.

On top of that, Pakistan has declared "open war" against Afghanistan following a series of cross-border attacks overnight. Pakistani Defense Minister Khawaja Mohammad Asif accused the Taliban of turning Afghanistan "into a colony of India."
data.author: Eddie Pan

data.title: Duolingo Stock Crashes over 20% as Management Chooses User Expansion over Immediate Profits
data.description:
Duolingo stock (DUOL) plummeted by 23% in early trading on Friday to $90.76. This drastic sell-off happened after the company revealed it would actively slow down its efforts to make money from users in order to keep those users happy and engaged. The goal is to reach 100 million daily active users by 2028, but shareholders are worried about what this means for the company's bank account right now.+1

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Duolingo Is Sacrificing Revenue to Fix User Growth

For the past two years, Duolingo has been very successful at getting users to pay for subscriptions or watch ads. While this made the company profitable, it also made the app less enjoyable for free users. As a result, the number of new people joining the app started to slow down in late 2025.

Management aims to fix this issue by reducing the friction for free learners. Instead of constantly asking users to pay, the company will focus on making the app more fun, which they hope will lead to more people recommending it to friends. Analysts like Wyatt Swanson from D.A. Davidson believe this is a necessary move, writing that previous efforts to monetize had led to "disgruntled users and a meaningful negative impact to 'word-of-mouth' marketing."

Duolingo's Soft Guidance Worries the Market

Investors did not take the news well because Duolingo also lowered its financial outlook for 2026. The company now expects revenue to be lower than what Wall Street analysts previously predicted. Even though the company beat revenue estimates for the final quarter of 2025, the promise of slower growth in 2026 was enough to cause the stock crash.

Analysts on Wall Street are split on the strategy. While some understand the long-term goal, others are punishing the stock for the short-term pain. KeyBanc analyst Justin Patterson noted that "While we believe this is the right long-term move, the near-term effect is clear." Because of this uncertainty, multiple firms cut their price targets for the stock by a significant amount.

Duolingo Plans to Offer More AI Features

To achieve its goals, Duolingo plans to offer more of its AI features, like the popular "Video Call with Lily," to all users rather than keeping them locked behind a paywall. While this will help attract new users, it also costs more money to run those AI servers, which will reduce the company's profit margins this year.

To support the stock price during this transition, the company authorized a $400 million share buyback program. This shows leadership believes the stock is undervalued, but it may not be enough to stop the bleeding if the user growth targets are not met quickly.

Is Duolingo a Good Stock to Buy?

On TipRanks, Duolingo stock (DUOL) has a Hold consensus rating based on five Buys, 10 Holds, and one Sell rating. The average 12-month DUOL price target of $139.64 implies 48.9% upside potential from current levels. Over the past year, DUOL shares have fallen 69%.
data.author: Annika Masrani

data.title: As Broadcom's (AVGO) Q1 Earnings Approach, Let's Look at Who Owns the AI Chip Stock
data.description:
Semiconductor and networking solutions provider Broadcom (AVGO) will announce its fiscal first-quarter results on March 4. AVGO stock has rallied 51% over the past year due to demand for the company's custom artificial intelligence (AI) chips, especially for AI inference, and its networking products. However, shares are down 7% year-to-date amid concerns about an AI bubble. That said, Wall Street remains bullish on AVGO stock ahead of Q1 FY26 earnings and sees attractive upside potential from current levels.

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Wall Street expects Broadcom to report Q1 FY26 EPS (earnings per share) of $2.02, implying more than 26% year-over-year growth. Revenue is projected to rise 29% to $19.22 billion.

Now, according to TipRanks' Ownership Tool, public companies and individual investors own 45.92% of Broadcom. They are followed by mutual funds, ETFs, other institutional investors, and insiders at 25.73%, 22.07%, 4.40%, and 1.88%, respectively.
data.author: Sirisha Bhogaraju

data.title: U.S. Stock Futures Fall amid AI Concerns, January Wholesale Inflation Report
data.description:
U.S. stock futures fell on Friday morning as investors remain concerned about AI-led disruption to sectors like software and financials, as well as fears of an AI bubble. Even chip giant Nvidia's (NVDA) stellar earnings failed to lift investor sentiment. Meanwhile, investors reacted negatively to January's producer price index (PPI) reading. The measure of wholesale inflation rose 0.5% (headline PPI) for the month, higher than the 0.3% expected by economists polled by Dow Jones. Futures on the Nasdaq 100 (NDX), the S&P 500 (SPX), and the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) fell 1.00%, 0.92%, and 1.20%, respectively, at 8:45 a.m. EST on February 27.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

During Thursday's regular trading, the three major indexes traded mixed. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.54% and 1.18%, respectively, while the Dow Jones eked out a small gain of 0.03%. Friday marks the final trading day of February, a turbulent month that shook tech stocks amid fears of AI disruption.

Turning to trending stocks, Netflix (NFLX) stock rallied 8.3% in Friday's pre-market trading after the streaming giant decided not to raise its bid for Warner Bros. Discovery's (WBD) assets to match a new bid from Paramount Skydance (PSKY). Shares of PSKY were up 7.7% in reaction to the news.

Meanwhile, Block (XYZ) stock rallied 20% after the fintech announced that it is laying off 4,000 employees. Also, the company issued a solid outlook for Q1 2026 and the full year. Dell Technologies (DELL) stock surged 12%, driven by upbeat Q4 results. However, shares of cybersecurity company Zscaler (ZS) tanked more than 11% after its Q2 FY26 deferred revenue and billings missed expectations.

Also, CoreWeave (CRWV) stock dropped 12% as the AI-powered cloud company's Q4 adjusted EBITDA lagged the Street's estimates.
data.author: Sirisha Bhogaraju

data.title: IonQ (IONQ) vs. D-Wave Quantum (QBTS): Which Quantum Computing Stock Looks Stronger after Earnings?
data.description:
Quantum computing stocks IonQ (IONQ) and D-Wave Quantum (QBTS) reported quarterly results this week, but the market reaction was very different. IonQ shares jumped after a strong Q4 revenue beat and upbeat guidance, while D-Wave struggled after reporting weaker-than-expected Q4 results.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

The contrast shows a shift in what investors are looking for. Instead of focusing only on long-term technology potential, investors now want evidence of real revenue and early commercial use.

Quarterly Highlights

IonQ Stock

IonQ delivered a strong quarter and exceeded expectations by a wide margin. The company reported Q4 revenue of $61.9 million, far above estimates of about $40 million. Its adjusted loss was also smaller than expected.

Guidance was the bigger driver. IonQ forecast first-quarter revenue of $48 million to $51 million and full-year revenue of $225 million to $245 million, both ahead of Wall Street projections. The company also reported full-year 2025 revenue of about $130 million, becoming the first publicly traded quantum computing company to surpass $100 million in annual sales.

The results suggested customers are beginning to use quantum computing services in real workloads rather than only experimental testing.

D-Wave Quantum Stock

D-Wave reported a weaker quarter. The company posted Q4 revenue of $2.75 million, below estimates of $3.75 million, and a larger-than-expected loss.

The stock had initially risen in sympathy after IonQ's results but pulled back once D-Wave released its own earnings. Despite the weak quarter, the company announced several developments, including a system sale, defense-related partnerships, and a multi-year quantum computing service agreement with a large corporate customer.

Roth Capital analyst Sujeeva De Silva kept a Buy rating on the stock but lowered the price target, pointing to higher operating expenses after D-Wave's January 2026 agreement to acquire Quantum Circuits, a developer of gate-model quantum hardware. The deal is meant to broaden D-Wave's technology beyond its current annealing systems, though it will raise costs in the near term. 

Which Quantum Computing Stock Looks Stronger?

Both companies are early-stage and still unprofitable, but the latest results explain the different market reaction. IonQ's earnings showed clearer revenue growth and reduced uncertainty for investors. D-Wave, meanwhile, highlighted future potential, yet its current revenue remains limited.

According to the TipRanks Stock Comparison Tool, analysts still rate QBTS a Strong Buy with an average price target of about $41.82, implying significant upside. Meanwhile IonQ carries a Moderate Buy consensus with an average price target near $63.82, implying roughly 56% upside from current levels.

In short, analysts see more valuation upside in D-Wave, but investors are currently favoring IonQ's stronger near-term business momentum.
data.author: Shalu Saraf

data.title: A Unique Company Offering an 'Attractive Entry Point,' Says Rosenblatt About Palantir Stock
data.description:
"N of 1" is a term Palantir (NASDAQ:PLTR) CEO Alex Karp uses to describe the company as a unique player in the AI software market with no direct competitors.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

It's a bold, almost arrogant way of saying they see themselves as totally unmatched, a way of signaling that, in Karp's view, no other company delivers comparable value.

Is it justified? Rosenblatt analyst John McPeake seems to think so. "Yes, Palantir Really Is an 'N of 1'… With a "rule of 40" (4Q revenue growth of 70% plus adjusted operating margin of 57%) of 127% and 720bp of rev growth acceleration in 4Q, Palantir is indeed the 'N of 1' that CEO Alex Karp claims," the analyst said.  

Palantir blends its proprietary infrastructure software with "best-in-class technology practitioners" to deliver fast, high-value solutions for enterprises and governments worldwide. McPeake says he has seen the company grow from a loss-making, services-focused startup in the early 2000s into a software leader with repeatable solutions, now generating 84% gross margins and 51% operating margins. "In enterprise software, we think Palantir will add more free cash flow dollars in 2026 than any software company except for SAP," McPeake further added. "We think Palantir is currently the only stack-agnostic company in technology that can provide an integrated enterprise platform for the rapid deployment of AI."

Palantir's momentum has been driven by close partnerships with governments and defense agencies, along with fast, high-value deployments at major global enterprises, including the U.S. DoD, the CIA, BP, Merck, and General Mills. McPeake's conversations with several customers suggest there is still significant expansion potential within their existing base. The company's "biggest moat" lies in the synergy between its "polymathic engineering team" and its extensive, mission-critical, battle-tested infrastructure and integration software. With strong demand from both traditional IT modernization and emerging enterprise AI projects, McPeake sees Palantir as well-positioned to achieve double-digit top- and bottom-line growth over the next decade.

Famously, Palantir's valuation is often mentioned as a turn-off for some. Indeed, a review of the biggest wealth-generating technology companies since 1981 shows that, even with its trailing twelve-month price-to-sales ratio dropping from a peak of 153x to 75x, Palantir remains an outlier.

But McPeake thinks the valuation is justified. "If one looks at the companies that have created the most value in technology when they were a similar size to Palantir, none of them was able to grow as fast as Palantir is forecasted to grow in year 8 (equivalent to Palantir's guidance in 2026)," the analyst explained. Moreover, at least two of those companies – Facebook and Google – relied on major transformative acquisitions midway through that period, while Palantir's growth has been entirely organic.

Given the stock has declined by 34.4% from last year's highs, McPeake thinks the shares now offer an "attractive entry point." As such, McPeake initiated coverage of PLTR stock with a Buy rating, backed by a $150 price target. Should the figure be met, investors will be pocketing returns of 10% a year from now. (To watch McPeake's track record, click here)

The Street's average target is actually a more exuberant $188.82, a figure that points toward 12-month gains of 39%. On the rating front, based on a mix of 14 Buys, 4 Holds and 2 Sells, the stock claims a Moderate Buy consensus rating. (See Palantir stock forecast)
data.author: Marty Shtrubel

data.title: Dow Jones Slumps on Concerning PPI Inflation Data
data.description:
The Dow Jones (DJIA) is set to open Friday lower following a disappointing inflation update from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS).

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

The U.S. Producer Price Index (PPI) rose 0.5% month-over-month and 2.9% year-over-year in January. Both figures were above the consensus estimates of 0.3% and 2.6%, respectively. The PPI tracks the prices that producers charge for their goods and services and is often used as an early indicator of inflation.

Annual Core CPI Growth Rises to 10-Month High

Core PPI, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, notched a monthly gain of 0.8% while growing 3.6% annually, the highest since March 2025. Again, both figures tallied above their estimates of 0.3% and 3.0%, respectively.

The rise in PPI was mostly attributed to a monthly increase of 0.8% in services, marking the highest level since July 2025, while goods prices fell by 0.3%. Over 20% of the increase in services came from a 14.4% jump in margins for professional and commercial equipment wholesaling.
data.author: Eddie Pan
